I suddenly remembered one of the reasons why I started this 100 Days Build in Public challenge: Simon Willison.

He‚Äôs an incredibly prolific writer. One time he talked about how he manages to be so productive, and he mentioned that he once did 100 consecutive days of content creation. Combined with his years of writing experience, he can now quickly turn the information he absorbs into writing every day, maintaining a high-output state. This idea stuck with me, and that night, on a bit of an impulse, I decided to give it a try myself.

The ‚Äúpower of 100‚Äù is real ‚Äî once you go through it, you truly experience all the ups and downs. I think it‚Äôs worth doing at least once. It‚Äôs like a burst of impulsive passion or impulse spending ‚Äî only through time and real experience can you grasp the real sweetness and bitterness of it.

Although I‚Äôve always believed that frontend or client-side work is more visible ‚Äî easier to show results ‚Äî while backend work (especially in the early stages) often looks like simple CRUD operations until it reaches a certain scale, I‚Äôve realized that doing frontend or client development is actually incredibly demanding and often underappreciated. From my past experience, frontend and client-side work usually consumes a disproportionate amount of effort ‚Äî maybe because I‚Äôm not a seasoned frontend or mobile engineer.

Now, with tools like Cursor + ChatGPT, many things are easier to cover, but the real challenge lies in continuous tuning and testing. Many times, you think you‚Äôve communicated your idea clearly, but the actual result can turn out quite different.

Day 6Ô∏è‚É£7Ô∏è‚É£

Marketing is crucial, especially in the early stage of a project. My two recent open-source projects both gained initial momentum by being shared in the right circles and platforms. They got in front of the right audience from day one. Then it‚Äôs all about expanding exposure‚Äîgetting your product or project seen in more places. Even if it doesn‚Äôt attract attention immediately, it can have a long-term effect. People will gradually trickle in. What you need to do is keep iterating.

Even though these are just open-source projects, the approach is essentially a PMF (Product-Market Fit) journey. I‚Äôm learning a lot through this:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Good wine still needs marketing. A great idea may go unnoticed if you don‚Äôt know how to market it‚Äîand you might miss the window of opportunity.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Sometimes you‚Äôre not sure if your idea is actually a good one. But if someone gives you that initial validation, it can make a huge difference. And even if the first idea isn‚Äôt the one, it might evolve into something powerful. Often, you don‚Äôt realize its potential until later.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Speed is everything, especially in the age of AI. I keep telling my friends this: if you have an idea, just do it. Even a one-week delay might cost you the moment. The goal isn‚Äôt to build something perfect‚Äîit‚Äôs to go from 0 to 1. You‚Äôll likely get something valuable out of it.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Build your own distribution channels. Think of yourself as the maker‚Äîbut also the distributor. Channels matter.

That‚Äôs about it. Easier said than done, but action speaks louder than words. By the way, someone influential tagged my project today. ü§û Hope it brings more visibility by this Friday.

Honestly, I‚Äôve been treating this #100Days challenge like writing a diary, haha. The truth is, I can‚Äôt always produce solid progress every single day. Sometimes my commits aren‚Äôt full features or polished modules. People are visual creatures‚ÄîI get that. I‚Äôm not breaking things down into technical pieces on purpose. Also, I‚Äôm not a content creator, so I don‚Äôt have the skills to ‚Äúcook up‚Äù flashy updates. I just share my thoughts and recent learnings‚Äîfreely and casually.

entry.title: [Iter-X] 64/100days
entry.content:
Day 6Ô∏è‚É£4Ô∏è‚É£

Immersed in a sea of data, endlessly exploring. Today I‚Äôve been calibrating the transformation from WGS84 to GCJ02 coordinate systems. Some of the previous data had location inaccuracies, so I‚Äôm adjusting the logic to fix it. Hopefully I can finish refining the scripts this week and start large-scale POI processing. Related images are also being crawled, and will later be uploaded in batches to OSS.

When dealing with images and videos, the two most costly factors are usually: 1. Storage and 2. Bandwidth. Storage tends to be cheaper, and we can optimize costs by implementing cold/hot storage separation. But bandwidth is where costs can spiral, so we pay extra attention there.

Typically, we generate several thumbnail versions of each image. In most cases, a thumbnail of just a few dozen KB is sufficient, especially on mobile screens. With lossless compression, we can reduce file sizes of high-res images significantly. And we can even sacrifice some resolution without noticeable impact to the human eye ‚Äî unless you zoom in. That‚Äôs why we strike a balance between visual quality and cost by generating a few common thumbnail sizes.

Some systems even support on-the-fly image resizing via URL parameters. This avoids the need to store multiple versions, though it requires generating images in real-time. However, if paired with a CDN, you only need to generate the image on the first request, which is totally acceptable. There‚Äôs no silver bullet ‚Äî only solutions that best match your scenario and budget.

The current map tiles don‚Äôt offer enough customization, so I‚Äôll just make do for now. I‚Äôve adjusted the overall color scheme first‚Äîstarting with subtraction before addition. Making the map truly smooth and easy to use will definitely take some serious effort.

Today, I came across a sentence: ‚ÄúNetflix today is very different. It‚Äôs not a library ‚Äî it‚Äôs an experience.‚Äù

While the original article had a different message, this line really resonated with me and sparked some thoughts. The idea is that Netflix used to be more like a library or a search engine‚Äîyou‚Äôd come, find a movie, and watch it. Now, it‚Äôs become more of an experience. It uses your watch history, preferences, and recommendation algorithms to push content you‚Äôre likely to enjoy. In other words, the content is no longer the star‚Äîthe experience is.

Of course, this is open to interpretation. For instance, in travel, many people have access to the same data‚Äîbut is content what really matters? To a degree, yes. Platforms like Xiaohongshu have built strong ecosystems and moats around content. But when it comes to travel, maybe what matters more is experience. While today‚Äôs technology might not yet offer true end-to-end service, we can still deliver a solid user experience. Sadly, as companies chase profit and growth, this often gets deprioritized or lost.

Experience might actually be a key driver of user retention. It‚Äôs something worth reflecting on. Today, many indie developers are capable of creating functional products‚Äîtools that hit the ‚Äúlibrary‚Äù level of usefulness. But crafting a truly great experience is another matter entirely. That‚Äôs a crucial dividing line. With enough time and energy, many people can build a passable product‚Äîbut standing out requires real skill, insight, and depth. It‚Äôs like that old saying: ‚ÄúGoing from 0 to 60 is easy. From 60 to 100 is where it gets tough.‚Äù

Still, it‚Äôs not impossible. The resources we have at our disposal within a given timeframe are more or less fixed. What we can grow is our awareness, our exposure to diverse people and ideas, and our ability to stay grounded. In a fast-moving world, we can ride the wave of FOMO to maintain momentum, but it‚Äôs the ‚Äúslow and steady‚Äù method that helps us weather the crash and deliver that one solid home run.

Just Fk**ing Do It.

Day 6Ô∏è‚É£2Ô∏è‚É£

These past two days, I‚Äôve been watching the first developer competition held by Xiaohongshu, and it got me thinking. I feel like indie developers and indie game developers are quite similar groups. The former probably has a larger population right now, but their survival rate is much lower. It‚Äôs a harsh reality‚Äîindie game devs can at least build interesting games and monetize directly through one-time purchases. For most indie app developers, though, it‚Äôs hard to earn more than what you‚Äôd get from a regular job. Some great apps can easily get ‚Äúhonored‚Äù by big companies, crushed by competition, or simply die in the early stages. The ones that make it out are rare.

It‚Äôs kind of surreal. Vibe Coding is becoming more popular now, and you can see a lot of solo devs creating cool apps, but most of them are driven by passion or a desire to create, not profit. B2C is brutally tough; B2B, on the other hand, is very reliant on business skills and connections.

This brings up the question: why do so many people still throw themselves into this path? Where do they end up? Maybe I can glimpse a bit of the answer through my own story, though one person‚Äôs experience probably doesn‚Äôt speak for the majority.

I think it‚Äôs both a process and an experience. I‚Äôve built many products in the past and provided product development services for individuals and businesses. In my case, the most profitable ones have always been B2B. I wonder if others feel the same. I‚Äôve always had this itch to create (a chronic itch that‚Äôs long overdue for treatment), and I keep dreaming of building something truly great. If it brings fame or fortune, even better‚Äîthat‚Äôs part of what keeps driving me to throw myself into new projects.

Ironically, I recently stumbled upon an old GitHub and blog intro I wrote:

I‚Äôm into the internet, traveling, reading, and listening to music ‚Äì still figuring out this whole ‚Äúliving life‚Äù thing.

I‚Äôm on a mission to balance the grind with some good old-fashioned living.

And recently while chatting with a friend, we joked: maybe East Asians just aren‚Äôt meant to enjoy life? I genuinely want work-life balance, but my inner workaholic always seems to take over. The most fair thing in life is that everyone gets 24 hours a day. Whenever you invest time and energy in one thing, you‚Äôre inevitably sacrificing another. Looking back at the ‚ÄúLife in Weeks‚Äù chart I drew in February‚Äîfrom birth to 2077 (my lifespan goal)‚Äîmaybe now isn‚Äôt the time for balance just yet.

Today I worked on integrating the map page. I‚Äôm currently tweaking the map‚Äôs appearance. The default tile layers are ugly and cluttered with too much irrelevant information. I need to simplify and adjust the color scheme. Once that‚Äôs done in the next couple of days, I‚Äôll share an update. The goal is to make it silky smooth and visually clean.

I‚Äôm about to start working on the map feature ‚Äî one of the most crucial aspects of trip planning visualization. For people with a strong sense of direction, like myself, displaying various POIs directly on the map is the most effective way to plan. Personally, once I look at a map and consider my available time and preferences, I can immediately visualize the entire trip‚Äôs flow and rhythm.

I especially enjoy saving interesting spots on Apple Maps or Google Maps. On the actual travel day, I decide what to visit based on the weather, mood, and time, making flexible decisions on the go. I see this as a nice balance between rigid planning and spontaneous travel. Since I have a good sense of direction and memory for places, I can mentally compute routes or even quickly adjust plans in case of unexpected situations.

But I know not everyone shares this habit or ability. What I want to provide is a way to use technology to reduce the cognitive load for people who find this challenging. For example, my partner is the complete opposite ‚Äî she can‚Äôt read maps at all and totally relies on me as her personal GPS. If I can build an app that works well for both of us, I believe it can meet the needs of most people out there.

entry.content:
Day6Ô∏è‚É£0Ô∏è‚É£

Today I came across an interesting article called Home-Cooked Software and Barefoot Developers. I want to reflect on it a bit and share some of my own thoughts.

Screenshots from the article

For a long time, mainstream software products have followed a general-purpose model‚Äîonce built, they can be used by many people repeatedly. We‚Äôve seen a shift from local applications to cloud-based ones, where data moves to the cloud and devices like phones and computers are just endpoints. Even brain-computer interfaces can be seen as another form of access. In the future, we might see a trend back toward local-first and non-generalized software, partly because of the rise of video coding and AI-assisted development. (Just today I open-sourced a service where over 95% of the work was done by AI‚ÄîI only handled a few key parts and barely looked at the code.)

This means in the future, anyone can build a product, and it doesn‚Äôt have to be general-purpose. It could be something made just for a specific event‚Äîa trip, a wedding, a one-time activity. It‚Äôs disposable, like a single-use item. A generation growing up with such low-cost output tools will naturally adapt to this mindset. The article also mentions that many future products will serve local communities first, which makes perfect sense. The world is not as perfect as the internet makes it seem‚Äîthere are still huge wealth gaps, underdeveloped regions, and people living below the poverty line. In some ways, AI could help address part of these issues.

At the moment, we‚Äôre in the industrial, high-modernism age of software, where these standardized, one-size-fits-all apps are made for us by people who don‚Äôt know much about us.

General-purpose or specialized? Large-scale or small-and-beautiful? Basic needs or long-tail demand? No commercial value = worthless? This article, with just a few slides and brief captions, is really worth a read. Like me, you might find yourself inspired or experience a shift in perspective.

It‚Äôs like this: for just $20 a month, you can now get a capable assistant who can handle the bulk of development for you. In a way, this is technological inclusion‚Äîeven long-tail and non-commercial projects now have a chance to exist and matter in the world.
